channel.title: RPGs in Need of Digital Toolsets
channel.description:
Hi! I was curious: what RPG are you currently playing that could benefit from a digital toolset?
I've realized that making a digital toolset is *really* within my wheelhouse, and I'd love to enable digital play for smaller games.
I've asked elsewhere but I keep getting suggestions like *GURPS* or *World of Darkness*, which are... bigger than I want. I'm looking at games that are PbtA/FitD/adjacent. One or two authors. My shortlist right now includes games like *NOVA*, *ICON*, *Fellowship*, etc.
If you could pull up a character sheet (or a "GM screen" with all your NPCs and players), click some buttons and have dice roll in your Discord channel, and that's about it, what systems need some love?
TIA!

item.title: RPGs in Need of Digital Toolsets
item.dc:creator: @olivetree
item.description:
@olivetree wrote:

I’m actually working on software for playing galactic 2e and going rogue 2e online. I’m making it in Godot, which might be overkill, but it’s the tool I know best.

I’ve made a ton of progress on it, and I’m grateful that the designers have given it their blessing. I’d say it’s about 70-80% done. But my life has gotten pretty busy recently and I might not be able to dive back into it until the fall. If all goes well, my ambition would definitely be to make tools for more BOB games.

I’m having fun making a bespoke tool for g2e/gr2e (Star Wars fonts and all that), but for a future project, maybe something generic that can handle any BOB game would be ideal.

@CitizenKeen – Not sure if you’re still interested in this kind of project, but I’m curious what you had in mind. Like I said, an executable built in Godot miiiight be overkill for this project. I’m learning JS, React, etc, right now, and I’m tempted to try to port my work over and just make it a website at some point. Would be curious to hear your thoughts!

@ChristopherA wrote:

Exactly.

I ended writing a tool that put both sides of the cards side-by-side as a single image, and did some tricks with premade stacks of cards. Your can also “hide” some zones.

But but those tricks don’t quite solve flipping and shuffling needs, just sort of half-assed way to work good enough for some playtesting.

— Christopher Allen

item.description:
@ChristopherA wrote:

I did try Randy Lubin’s “StorySynth” which was interesting, but didn’t quite serve my needs. I converted is “Save the Galaxy” supplement for Riley Rithal’s “Galactic 2e” to use it, and it is interesting and playable.

You can see it at:

https://storysynth.org/Shuffled/1yGHuFhPP9DDrs_9WG2TeSzl1VTRxLjFk2i0kwOJvgcE/

It should still work (though his tool has evolved some since I tried). The data behind it is at:

docs.google.com

StorySynth - Save the Galaxy

Sheet1 deck,header,body,back option,styleTemplate,dark option,style,<style> .full-page-background { background: <p/> <p/> Linen; } </style> option,gameTitle,"Save the Galaxy!" option,byline,A Plot Guide for "Galactic 2e" option,gameBlurb,This...

The sheet has some useful tricks. But without user index cards, it didn’t really work for my Tableau game.

– Christopher Allen

item.title: RPGs in Need of Digital Toolsets
item.dc:creator: @ChristopherA
item.description:
@ChristopherA wrote:

I’ve made some progress with “reusable RPG components”, which you can see with the launch of this week’s Tableau Kickstarter:

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/christophera/tableau-twilight-road-and-gate-watch-playsets-quickstarter?ref=9eh81p

I still haven’t found a good online solution — none of the current RPG tools even do basic index cards for story games. The best solution I’ve come up with so far is to upload all my tableau cards to Miro (a business white board site) and use their post-it notes features.

– Christopher Allen

item.dc:creator: @Derek_Fetters
item.description:
@Derek_Fetters wrote:

Not a Gauntlet or PbtA game, but Two-Fisted Tales, by Matthew Stevens. It’s a '30s Era pulp adventure game with a dice mechanic that I’m having difficulty emulating in Roll20. It’s 2d10, but they roll 0-9, explode on a 9, and one die generates a positive number (the bonus die), the other generates a negative number (the penalty die). Add the result of the roll to an ability score and compare to a target number.

item.dc:creator: @ChristopherA
item.description:
@ChristopherA wrote:

I’d really like to see a digital toolset for the many and various Belonging Outside Belonging gmless games. Needs a character manager for entry of strong, tempting, and weak moves, as well as token management per player. Also same types of moves but for story elements assigned to players, but with tokens flow in/out of common pool. Lastly some type of index card “truths”.

— Christopher Allen
